rev.diff:
Line 40: Line 40:
=== Corruption ===
=== Corruption ===
â
While in office, political corruption in the Mubarak administration's Ministry of Interior has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system that is necessary to secure the prolonged presidency. Such corruption has led to the frequent imprisonment of political figures and young activists without trials, illegal undocumented hidden detention facilities, and rejecting universities, mosques, newspapers staff members based on political inclination.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} On a personnel level, each individual officer can and will violate citizens' privacy in his area, using unconditioned arrests, common torture and abuse of power, depending on simply brute force, rather than law, to enforce order in the officer's designated area.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} This has resulted in the common belief that "A policeman is more dangerous than a criminal".{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
+
While in office, political corruption in the Mubarak administration's Ministry of Interior has risen dramatically, due to the increased power over the institutional system that is necessary to secure the prolonged presidency. Such corruption has led to the frequent imprisonment of political figures and young activists without trials, illegal undocumented hidden detention facilities, and rejecting universities, mosques, newspapers staff members based on political inclination.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} On a personnel level, each individual officer can and will violate citizens' privacy in his area, using unconditioned arrests, common torture and abuse of power, depending on simply brute force, rather than law, to enforce order in the officer's designated area.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
The rise to power of powerful business men in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] in the government and People's Assembly led to massive waves of anger during the years of [[Ahmed Nazif]]'s government. As a result, frequent laws and bills are passed, with undergiant monopolists (such as [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s) influence serving personal and corporational financial interests rather than public's.
The rise to power of powerful business men in the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] in the government and People's Assembly led to massive waves of anger during the years of [[Ahmed Nazif]]'s government. As a result, frequent laws and bills are passed, with undergiant monopolists (such as [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s) influence serving personal and corporational financial interests rather than public's.
